data.title: Great white shark Brunswick moving on from Îles-de-la-Madeleine
data.meta_description: The latest fix on Brunswick's position shows him still in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, but he seems to have decided to head northwest.
data.text:
The latest fix on Brunswick's position shows him still in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, but he seems to have decided to head northwest.

Article content

Brunswick the great white shark, whose foray into the Gulf of St. Lawrence last month made headlines around the world, seems to have had enough of the Îles-de-la-Madeleine.

The 2.7-metre shark was tagged with a tracking chip last February off the coast of Georgia and near the town of Brunswick by researchers working for Ocearch, a non-profit group that monitors the movements of several marine species.

Article content

His trip north along the eastern seaboard brought him to Grand Manan Island in New Brunswick and then to Cape Breton. But Brunswick’s decision to proceed into the Gulf of St. Lawrence and investigate Île-du-Havre-aux-Maisons, located in the eastern portion of the Îles-de-la-Madeleine archipelago, was, according to Ocearch, an apparent first for a great white shark.

While the latest fix on Brunswick’s position shows him still in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, he seems to have decided to head northwest, putting distance between himself and the islands.

Ocearch is tracking Brunswick in an effort to establish his migration and feeding habits. The organization also tracks whales, sea turtles, dolphins and alligators.
